description: From Mexican Spanish estampida (“a stampede”), estampido (“a crackling”), akin to estampar (“to stamp”).

entries.meaning: A wild, headlong scamper, or running away, of a number of animals; usually caused by fright; hence, any sudden flight or dispersion, as of a crowd or an army in consequence of a panic.
examples: Synonyms: rush, flight, crush, jam, trampling

entries.meaning: (by extension) A situation in which many people in a crowd are trying to go in the same direction at the same time.
examples: The annual Muslim Hajj in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, which is attended by millions of pilgrims, has increasingly suffered from stampedes.

entries.meaning: (figurative) Any sudden unconcerted moving or acting together of a number of persons, as from some common impulse.
examples: a stampede toward US bonds in the credit markets

verbs.description: stampede (third-person singular simple present stampedes, present participle stampeding, simple past and past participle stampeded)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To run away in a panic; said of cattle, horses, etc., also of armies.
(transitive) To disperse by causing sudden fright, as a herd or drove of animals.
examples: Cattle are usually quiet after dark. Still I've known even a coyote to stampede your white herd.

entries.meaning: (of people) To move rapidly in a mass.
